content.question:
The following graphs show the sampling distributions for two different point estimators, <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, of the same population parameter.

Which of the following statements is true?

choices.label: Both <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are unbiased.
Both <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are biased.
<math alttext="X " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is biased, and <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is unbiased.
<math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is unbiased, and <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is biased.
The assessment of bias is not possible, because the sampling distributions display too much variability.

content.answer: Both <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are unbiased.

skill.text: Skill 4.B: Interpret statistical calculations and findings to assign meaning or assess a claim.
